data.text: Contents
Introduction

CPO  -  carbapenemase  producing  organisms.  Predominately  the  group  of organisms  identified  with  carbapenem  resistance  is  Enterobacteriaceae. Enterobacteriaceae are a large family of bacteria that usually live harmlessly in the gut of humans and animals. They are often associated with the most common causes of urinary tract infections, intra-abdominal and blood stream infections. They include species such as Escherichia coli, Klebsiella spp. and Enterobacter spp.

Carbapenems  are  an important  group  of antibiotics  normally reserved  for serious  infections  caused  by  resistant  gram  negative  bacteria  (including enterobacteriaceae).  They include  the antibiotics:  meropenem,  ertapenem, imipenem and doripenem.

Carbapenamases are enzymes produced by a small, but growing number of bacteria which are able to destroy carbapenem antibiotics. The emergence of CPO  is  a  major  public  health  concern,  with  a  rapid  increase  in  cases worldwide.  Although  still  relatively  rare  in  the  United  Kingdom,  these organisms are endemic in other areas of the world and there is a risk of introduction to the UK, and subsequent person-to-person spread in health care settings.

There are very limited options available to treat infections caused by CPO. In addition  to  this,  there  are  few  new  antibiotics  in  development  to  provide therapeutic cover for the next 10-20 years. Human infections with CPO are associated with poorer patient outcomes, increased morbidity, mortality and higher hospital costs
Scope
This policy outlines the process for the management and control of infection of patients with carbapenemase producing organisms (CPO) within the MSE.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust

Infection Prevention and Control Site Committee (IPCC) is responsible for the review of this policy at least every three years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control Legislation or guidance.

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has the  necessary  management  systems  in  place  to  enable  the  effective implementation  of this  policy  and  overall  responsibility  for  the  health  and safety of staff, patients and visitors

The  Site  Director  of  Infection  Prevention  and  Control  (DIPC)  is responsible for ensuring that there are effective and appropriate arrangements for the prevention and control of infection throughout the Trust.

Head of Infection Prevention and Control MSE - will give advice against this policy and ensure that all staff have access to this policy via the Trust Intranet, and ensure that it is updated every three years or in line with current national guidance.

The Infection Prevention and Control Teams (IPCT) are responsible for ensuring all staff are made aware of this policy and advising ward staff on control measures, providing them with the necessary advice

All Staff must comply with this policy and act in a responsible manner, liaising with the IPCT in a timely manner if in need of advice or support. All staff have a responsibility to ensure that Infection Prevention and Control is embedded into their everyday practice and applied consistently at all times
Screening

Any patient who has received hospital care outside the United Kingdom is at risk  of  carrying  CPO,  therefore  strict  active  screening  of  any  patient transferred across borders into a healthcare facility in the United Kingdom is advised

data.text: If the first result is negative, two further negative samples will be required and a risk assessment undertaken before removing the patient from isolation. The
screens should be taken 48 hours apart (i.e. if the initial sample was taken on day 0 the other two samples should be taken on days 2 and 4)

If a patient found to be positive for CPO and has spent time in an open ward or bay before the positive result was known, the other patients on that ward will require screening. The IPCT will provide guidance on contact tracing and screening
In the event of an outbreak of CPO (two or more cases linked in time and place) the Trust outbreak policy will be followed.
Transmission
CPO can spread person to person by faecal contamination of the hands, transferred from an environmental source or contaminated equipment.
Treatment
Antibiotic treatment options are limited and determined by sensitivity testing results. Any treatment, including surgical prophylaxis, should be discussed with a Consultant Microbiologist
Infection Prevention Precautions

Patients who meet the at-risk criteria or who are found to be positive for CPO must be isolated in a single room with en-suite facilities and with the door closed at all times and Source Isolation sign displayed

A patient who is found to be positive for CPO should remain in isolation for the duration of their stay in hospital even if they subsequently test negative, as the patient may continue to be positive at an undetected level

Note  that  the  most  important  means  of  CPO  spread is  via  contaminated hands. A high standard of hand hygiene must be maintained at all times before and in between each patient contact. Encourage the patient to clean their hands before meals and after using the toilet/commode.
Single use disposable long sleeved aprons and gloves should be used

Visitors are not required to wear protective clothing unless involved in the patient's personal care, when an apron should be worn. Visitors taking part in care activities must be provided with PPE, shown how to apply and remove it and  the  correct  waste  streams  to  dispose  of  PPE  into.  Visitors  must  be advised to wash their hands immediately prior to leaving the isolation room
and must not wander around the ward or visit other patients. Visitors who are undertaking multiple hospital visits must be advised to visit the affected patient last.

Patients with confirmed or suspected CPO should ideally have designated staff to care for them, but it is accepted that this may not be practicable and strict adherence to source isolation precautions must be maintained. Staff such as Allied Health Professionals (AHP) should, where practical, see all other patients prior to those with confirmed or suspected CPO and adherence to source isolation precautions must be maintained. There must be precautions identified for support staff e.g. catering and cleaning staff

Equipment must be kept to an absolute minimum and designated for the sole use of the patient in isolation. This includes blood pressure monitoring equipment, tympanic thermometer, dressing trolley and commode. Equipment may only be used on other patients after it has received thorough decontamination

  Linen must be changed daily and disposed of in a red alginate bag and then into a white linen bag. Used linen must be disposed of promptly .Linen bags must not be placed on the floor of the isolation room- this reduces the potential risk of environmental contamination
Environmental cleaning and decontamination, with an enhanced focus on frequently touched areas must be carried out
Clinical waste must be placed in an orange waste bag
Patients can use crockery and cutlery from the main kitchen, no special precautions are required

If a patient has had 3 negative results for CPO following testing (and the only indication for isolation was transfer/admission/contact tracing screening) isolation can be discontinued and the patient can be nursed in a main bay. No further screening is required
The transfer of patients to other departments must be avoided where possible. It is preferable for investigations to be undertaken on the ward i.e. x-ray
If the patient requires a planned visit to other departments this must be done with the full involvement of the IPCT, who will advise on the precautions that must be taken
Areas such as theatres will have more detailed plans on how to accommodate patients with confirmed/ suspected CPO, including decontamination with hydrogen peroxide
If a patient needs to be transferred urgently due to clinical reasons (i.e. critical care), the receiving area should be fully aware of the patient's' diagnosis and required precautions

Renal haemodialysis patients: any patient who has who has had away from base dialysis (holiday dialysis) abroad at a listed hot country must be dialysed in a single room until they have had one negative screen.

If a confirmed or suspected CPO patient is transferred without the full knowledge of the receiving ward this is a Serious Incident and a Datix report must be completed in accordance with the Trust's Incident Reporting Policy. The IPCT must additionally be informed, to assess the need for further screening of potential contacts
Environmental Cleaning
Domestic Services must be made aware that the patient is receiving special precautions so that they can provide any necessary additional cleaning equipment
Yellow colour-coded cleaning equipment must be available and the room. The room will be cleaned daily by The Cleaning Response Team(CRT)
The room must be cleaned daily with a sporicidal agent e.g. Tristel or DIFF-X solution

Following discharge the room should have all linen and curtains removed. The room should have an initial clean with detergent and hot water. Following this the room must have hydrogen peroxide decontamination
Pillows must be disposed of. The mattress must be checked as safe to re-use
All disposable equipment to be disposed of including, unused dressings, ointments, tapes, wipes, gloves etc.
Staff must ensure that all equipment that has been in contact with the patient remains in the room and is cleaned as part of the hydrogen peroxide decontamination
Training Requirements

All Trust staff to undertake Mandatory Infection Prevention and Control updates and Donning and Doffing updates. The IPCT has primary responsibility for providing training on the policy where needed. Managers have the responsibly to support the IPCT by ensuring that staff are able to attend training sessions in response to identified needs

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE IPCC's, which  are  the  specialist  groups  with  the  authority  to  approve  MSE  IPC Polices.  These  will  then  be  forwarded  to  the  Document  control  team  for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Director of Harm Free Care of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
